body:
Strange, what sort of devices are participating in the transfer?
Is the file pointed by the symlink synced too?

We don't usually modify permissions or mtimes on symlinks, because they don't have any, so it's strange how this is happening.

Both are just PCs on Linux, home and work ones, no other devices use this repo. Symlinked file is perfectly synced long ago. I also use syncthing-inotify on both ends but I doubt it can be the culprit. I'll observe this further, for now it seems to be fine.
So If I understand correctly the symlink target is part of the repo?

One of them, yes. Another symlink points to an outer file and that file was also "corrupted" in that way. To be precise, the outer file is the "fastboot" program from the Android SDK. The SDK huge so I keep it elsewhere, but ~/bin is in my PATH to provide useful shortcuts and scripts for my user. This file is the only one that was reset from the whole platform-tools directory, now it looks like this:

```
drwxr-xr-x  4 rkfg rkfg    4096 Dec 12 00:52 .
drwxr-x--- 13 rkfg rkfg    4096 Dec 17 13:57 ..
-rwxr-xr-x  1 rkfg rkfg 1318951 Dec 12 00:52 adb
drwxr-xr-x  2 rkfg rkfg    4096 Dec 12 00:52 api
-rwxr-xr-x  1 rkfg rkfg   47828 Dec 12 00:52 dmtracedump
-rwxr-xr-x  1 rkfg rkfg  221198 Dec 12 00:52 etc1tool
-rw-rw-rw-  1 rkfg rkfg  215626 Jan  1  1970 fastboot
-rwxr-xr-x  1 rkfg rkfg   10031 Dec 12 00:52 hprof-conv
-rw-r--r--  1 rkfg rkfg  753215 Dec 12 00:52 NOTICE.txt
-rw-r--r--  1 rkfg rkfg   16508 Dec 12 00:52 source.properties
-rwxr-xr-x  1 rkfg rkfg  780843 Dec 12 00:52 sqlite3
drwxr-xr-x  2 rkfg rkfg    4096 Dec 12 00:52 systrace
```

There were no error messages for the time interval when that happened yesterday. Previously there were some chmod errors because I had broken symlinks for some time, moved the entire outside directory they were pointing to. The target files in question were not in that directory, but I have some errors for other files (symlinks, actually) like:

```
INFO: Puller (folder "bin", file "***.py"): shortcut: chmod /home/rkfg/bin/***.py: no such file or directory
```

The error itself is correct, this symlink was broken. Maybe it affects other symlinks in the same directory.

Can you run with STTRACE=scanner,model and then grep out the filenames which are symlinks?
I suggest you change permissions on the target of the symlink and see if that generates any output.
It seems that a symlink is somehow recognized as a standard file.

Also, is `ls /home/rkfg/bin/***.py` definitely a symlink?

What versions of syncthing are you running on all participating parties?
Are all PC's linux?

Both are 0.10.20.
Hmm, by the way on the other side "fastboot" is a regular file and its date is Jan 1, 1970. So it looks to me like in one of the previous versions symlinks were handled wrong and thus a regular file was created with zero timestamp and default permissions (but with contents of the symlink target file), which in turn was synced back and corrupted the original file. The same happens with another file, the scheme is a bit tricky though.
Side A:
~/bin/mpdel (the problematic file with constantly resetting timestamp/acl)
~/ownCloud/mplayer/mpdel -> ~/bin/mpdel (the symlink to the file above)
Both ~/bin and ~/ownCloud are synced with side B.

Side B:
~/bin/mpdel (the problematic file with constantly resetting timestamp/acl)
~/ownCloud/mplayer/mpdel (a **regular** file with zero timestamp and default acl, probably was created long ago when symlinks weren't working)

So even when I change the acl/timestamp for ~/bin/mpdel on any side it gets rewritten via that symlink because Side A receives a regular file named "~/ownCloud/mplayer/mpdel" with broken attrs and puts them to the symlink target (~/bin/mpdel). I believe this should not happen, if one tries to sync a file over a symlink (on the other end) this should be ignored and an error should be reported. I may be wrong though. On a side note, I hope cyclic links are handled well enough because this may actually happen and not just as file -> file but with several hops in between.

So as for the cause:

The only way I figured out mtime 0 and perms 666 could happen would be if a syncthing version which does not support symlinks receive a symlink from a newer version, causing it to create a gibberish file and then sending the gibberish back (because it would see that the symlink bit (which even if it is invalid in the old version) is unset and treat it as a change).

This was an incompatibility between versions which it seems we did not address. 
I am sorry about that.

Can you confirm that you did have versions prior to v0.10.7 running?

Now as to why this is still happening, I am not exactly sure. It should fix itself, meaning either A should get a file, or B should get a symlink, otherwise it should just look out of sync.
Can you set env var`STTRACE=model,scanner` and try to fix up the file manually and then provide the relevant log entries relating to the two files in question in order for me to figure out why it's not restoring itself?

The thing is that chmod +x affects the target, not the link, and it seems that the hybrid (link on one side file on the other side) is causing issues.
If you remove the hybrid thing, let the deletion sync across, and recreate it, I assume it should be fine?
The possible reason why it's not fixing itself could be due to #220, the files are of the same version, but of different types hence are assumed in sync.

Also, when B scans the hybrid, what are the flags that you are seeing?
I assume it's just skipped as nothing is assumed changed? 
Now if you change permissions on the hybrid (regular file) on B side, that should cause the symlink to be deleted on A's side and recreated as a standard file.

The other thing you could do in order for me to stop bothering you, and given the content you are synching is not sensitive, zip up the index directories from both A and B, and zip up the two files in question causing issues on both sides, so that I could get the problematic environment in question to see what's actually happening.

I don't have the hybrid now, I fixed the symlink on the other side. However, the issue is not gone. I suspect if I set the acl and mtime on both sides together, it will be fixed. Now it looks like ping-pong, I change it on one side, it gets propagated to another but after a rescan it once again resets to zero. I have the logs of this but they contain sensitive data (node IDs). Would it be ok if I drop them together with the indexes) to your email?
On a second thought, the indexes are pretty sensitive, unfortunately, so I can only provide the log files.

Node IDs are note sensitive at all: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/wiki/FAQ#should-i-keep-my-device-ids-secret

What do you mean by acl's and mtime? If it's a symlink it doesn't have mtime nor it has acls.
If it's a file, ACLs and Mtime should be synced properly as it's just a plain file.

> Given a device ID it's possible to find the IP address for that node, if global discovery is enabled on it.

That's why I don't want to publish my ID. I don't want anybody to know my IP anytime (it's dynamic but knowing the ID allows to find my current IP and be cryptographically sure it's mine).

I meant mode flags and mtime of the actual file, the symlink's target. Did some experimenting.

Now it looks like this:
1) I chmod/touch mpdel on side B.
2) Do a rescan on B.
3) Attributes are transferred to A.
4) Both A and B have the file with correct mtime/flags.
5) Do a rescan on A.
6) mpdel on A becomes "wrong" (zero mtime, 666 in flags)
7) It's transferred to B.

Another case:

1) I chmod/touch mpdel on side A.
2) Do a rescan on A.
3) Attributes are transferred to B.
4) Both A and B have the file with correct mtime/flags.
5) Do a rescan on B.
6) mpdel on B stays fine but on A it becomes "wrong" (zero mtime, 666 in flags)
7) It's transferred then back to B.

Can you provide `STTRACE=model,scanner` just replacing out the ID's and IPs on both sides as this is happening?

I'll try and reproduce this later today myself to figure out why this is happening, given it's my code that's causing it.

Looks to me like an inconsistency in the DB. I tried to create a symlink to some file on A, sync it to B, then replace the symlink with the file, changing its flags and mtime and after syncing it replaced the symlink on B. That was not the case from the very beginning of my issue, there were a symlink and a file living happily on both sides without preempting each other and that's possibly the root of the problem. I can't achieve the same behavior now, probably it could be only done via exploiting the old version bug. And answering your question regarding 0.10.7, probably yes, I've had all versions from the 0.10.x branch and they're always up to date. Can't say for sure from which version I migrated to 0.10.x though.

Log of Side A: http://pastebin.com/7cxwN9Kd
Log of Side B: http://pastebin.com/XEjGbANh
Please, save them locally as I set the expiration to 1 day. Tell me if I've redacted it too much and removed necessary data. To reproduce you can build an older version, sync some symlinks so the database state is pseudo-synced but actually there are plain files insted of symlinks on another side, then update the build to 0.10.20 and play with the files. Hopefully, it will behave alike.
Yeah, I'll try to play with new + old version and see if I can get it into this wicked state.

If I understand correctly you are not having issues with newly created files/symlinks, just with the legacy one which seems to have been corrupted due to version incompatibility?

The way around it would be to switch syncthing off on both sides, delete the index directory and let it rebuild the index.

> you are not having issues with newly created files/symlinks, just with the legacy one which seems to have been corrupted due to version incompatibility?

Seems to be it. I can't say though which version to consider legacy enough. The first file that started having issues was "naspower" which I use to turn my NAS on (via WOL) and off (via SSH), it has two symlinks, nason and nasoff respectively. So one day it stopped working and I found that its +x attribute was reset. I changed it back just to find another day that it was reset once again. It happened in 2014 for sure, probably in December.

> delete the index directory and let it rebuild the index.

Yeah, that should fix it. I, as a programmer myself, hate to delete problems irreversibly as they sometimes strike back. So while I have a stable reproducible error I prefer to investigate and fix it instead of getting rid of it the easy way. Looks like I did everything I could and researched it well enough so I'll backup the indexes and reset them.
Thanks, I'll try to replicate the behaviour and figure out what's happening given I know under what circumstances they happened.

And the mpdel mystery was probably resolved as well. I forgot that I have another node, a VPS server, that also syncs the "ownCloud" repo, it had the same issue (a file with zero mtime/default flags instead of a symlink) so it was actually replicated from that server though I fixed the symlink on my two desktop nodes and thought it was a database error. After fixing it there I don't have the issue.

That VPS "maintains itself" and autoupdates just fine (it has 0.10.20 for the record) so I forgot about it. It demonstrates that the code quality is quite great.

issue.title: Folder "" isn't making progress - check logs for possible root cause. Pausing puller for 1m0s.

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
!
    ,      .
      Linux        Windows (7,8.1)      :
12:26:00: Folder "420-a-2" isn't making progress - check logs for possible root cause. Pausing puller for 1m0s.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9034919/5833908/1fbfa17a-a169-11e4-967e-21cb81d62d50.png)

  -      ?

:          .

 !

body:
I have the same problem:
Machine A: broken symlink, reasonable type, modification date etc.
Machine B: text file (with destination inside), 1970-01-01, mode 666
Two Linux boxes, one runs a slightly older syncthing (0.10.19 from Arch LInux repos) and the other is self-updating (0.10.20 -> 0.10.21 on Ubuntu).

I have already stopped syncthing on both ends and deleted the index.  The issue, however, did not sort itself out.  What is the right course of action, here?  Should I delete the index _and_ delete all of those pseudo-symlinks?  Is there a magic way to convert the text files into symlinks?
I think the only thing you need to do is delete the symlink and delete the text file at the other end and recreate it once the deletion has propagated.

rename.to: Refuse files with unknown bits set
